name: Eiffel Tower
clues: I was built for a World's Fair in 1889
I was once the tallest man-made structure in the world
I'm made of iron and have three levels for visitors
I light up spectacularly at night, with a sparkling display every hour
funFacts: The Eiffel Tower was initially intended to be a temporary structure
It takes 20,000 light bulbs to make the Eiffel Tower sparkle at night
The Eiffel Tower grows by up to 15 cm (6 inches) in summer due to thermal expansion
Gustave Eiffel had an apartment at the top where he entertained guests like Thomas Edison
trivia: During cold weather, the tower shrinks by about 6 inches
It takes 60 tons of paint to cover the Eiffel Tower
The Eiffel Tower was almost demolished in 1909
There's a secret military bunker underneath the tower

name: Machu Picchu
clues: I'm an ancient citadel sitting high in the mountains, built in the 15th century
I was 'lost' to the outside world until 1911 when an explorer rediscovered me
My stone structures were built without mortar, with blocks cut to fit together perfectly
I sit nearly 8,000 feet above sea level with a dramatic mountain backdrop
funFacts: Machu Picchu means 'Old Peak' or 'Old Mountain' in the Quechua language
The site contains over 150 buildings ranging from temples to sanctuaries
It was built without the use of wheels, iron tools, or mortar
Many archaeologists believe it was built as an estate for Emperor Pachacuti
trivia: The citadel has a sophisticated drainage system that prevents flooding during heavy rains
The famous Intihuatana stone functions as a solar clock
Many of the site's buildings have astronomical alignments
Visitors are not allowed to enter with walking sticks unless they are elderly or disabled

name: Taj Mahal
clues: I'm a white marble mausoleum built by an emperor in memory of his favorite wife
My name translates to 'Crown of Palaces'
I'm one of the New Seven Wonders of the World
I appear to change color depending on the time of day
funFacts: The Taj Mahal took approximately 22 years to complete
Over 20,000 workers and 1,000 elephants were used to build it
The four minarets surrounding the tomb were designed to lean slightly outward to protect the main structure in case they collapsed
The precious stones used for inlay work were sourced from all over Asia
trivia: The calligraphy on the Great Gate increases in size as it reaches the top, creating the illusion of uniform size when viewed from below
There's a myth that Shah Jahan planned to build a mirror image of the Taj Mahal in black marble on the opposite bank of the river
During World War II, scaffolding was erected around the dome to mislead bomber pilots
The tomb changes color throughout the day – pinkish in the morning, white in the evening, and golden in the moonlight

name: Great Barrier Reef
clues: I'm the world's largest coral reef ecosystem
I'm so large I can be seen from outer space
I'm home to more than 1,500 species of fish
I stretch for over 2,300 kilometers along a coastline
funFacts: The Great Barrier Reef is composed of over 2,900 individual reefs and 900 islands
It's home to 30 species of whales, dolphins, and porpoises
The reef has been around for about 500,000 years in various forms
It's the world's biggest single structure made by living organisms
trivia: The blue starfish found on the reef is actually its own species, not just a color variation
The reef generates about $6 billion per year in tourism
There are 6 species of sea turtles that come to the reef to breed
Scientists have found medicinal compounds in reef organisms that can be used to treat diseases like cancer

name: Santorini
clues: I'm a volcanic island known for my stunning white buildings with blue domes
I'm believed by some to be the location of the lost city of Atlantis
My sunset views are considered among the most beautiful in the world
I have distinctive beaches with black, red, and white sand
funFacts: Santorini is essentially what remains after an enormous volcanic eruption that created a caldera
The island's official name is Thira, though Santorini is more commonly used
Houses are painted white to reflect the harsh summer sun
The island's volcanic soil contributes to its unique wine production
trivia: Santorini has no natural water sources, so most water is collected from rainfall or imported
The island's volcanic eruption around 1600 BCE was one of the largest in recorded history
There are only a handful of swimming pools on the island due to water scarcity
The local tomato varieties are uniquely sweet due to the volcanic soil

name: Pyramids of Giza
clues: I'm the oldest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, and the only one still in existence
I'm a complex of three main structures built as tombs for pharaohs
I was built using more than 2 million stone blocks, each weighing 2-30 tons
I've stood in my desert location for more than 4,500 years
funFacts: The Great Pyramid was the tallest man-made structure for over 3,800 years
The pyramids align almost perfectly with the cardinal points of a compass
They were originally covered with polished limestone that would have shone brilliantly in the sun
The largest pyramid was built for the Pharaoh Khufu and took about 20 years to build
trivia: The temperature inside the pyramids stays constant at about 20°C (68°F)
No mummies were actually found in the three main pyramids of Giza
Modern scientists still aren't entirely sure how the pyramids were built
The Great Pyramid of Giza is estimated to contain 2.3 million stone blocks

name: Northern Lights
clues: I'm a natural light display in the sky, particularly in high-latitude regions
I'm also known as Aurora Borealis in the northern hemisphere
I'm caused by disturbances in the magnetosphere by solar wind
I display dynamic patterns of brilliant lights that appear as curtains, rays, spirals, or flickers
funFacts: The Northern Lights occur when charged particles from the sun hit atoms in Earth's atmosphere
Different gases produce different colors - oxygen creates green and red, nitrogen creates blue and purple
They're visible from space and astronauts often photograph them from the International Space Station
The best time to see them is usually between September and March when dark hours are longest
trivia: The Vikings believed the Northern Lights were reflections from the shields of the Valkyries
In Finnish Lapland, they're called 'revontulet', meaning 'fox fires'
Some indigenous peoples believed whistling at the lights would summon them closer
There's a Southern Hemisphere equivalent called Aurora Australis or Southern Lights

name: Mount Fuji
clues: I'm the highest mountain in my country, at 3,776 meters
I'm an active volcano that last erupted in 1707
I'm considered sacred and have been a pilgrimage site for centuries
I'm known for my perfectly symmetrical cone shape
funFacts: Mount Fuji is actually three separate volcanoes stacked one on top of the other
The official climbing season is only two months long, from July to August
It was added to the World Heritage List as a Cultural Site in 2013
Over 200,000 people climb to the summit each year
trivia: There are more than 30 'suicide forests' at the base of Mount Fuji
The first person to climb Mount Fuji was a monk in 663 CE
Women were forbidden from climbing Mount Fuji until 1868
The mountain is divided into 10 stations, with paved roads going as far as the 5th station

name: Grand Canyon
clues: I'm a steep-sided canyon carved by a river over millions of years
I'm 277 miles (446 km) long and up to 18 miles (29 km) wide
My colorful landscape takes on amazing hues at sunrise and sunset
I expose nearly two billion years of Earth's geological history
funFacts: The Grand Canyon was formed by the Colorado River cutting channels through layers of rock over millions of years
It's not the deepest canyon in the world, but it's known for its overwhelming size and intricate landscape
The temperature at the bottom can be more than 20°F (11°C) warmer than at the rim
It contains some of the oldest exposed rock on Earth, dating back about 2 billion years
trivia: There's a small village called Supai at the bottom of the canyon that receives its mail by mule
About 5 million people visit the Grand Canyon each year
An inversion layer can sometimes fill the canyon with fog, creating a spectacular sight
There are approximately 1,000 caves in the Grand Canyon, but only 335 have been documented

name: Victoria Falls
clues: I'm one of the largest waterfalls in the world, based on combined width and height
I'm known locally as 'The Smoke That Thunders'
I form the border between two countries
I was named by a Scottish explorer for his queen
funFacts: Victoria Falls is the only waterfall in the world with a length of more than a kilometer and a height of more than 100 meters
During the rainy season, over 500 million liters of water plummet over the edge every minute
The spray from the falls can be seen from up to 50 km away
A naturally formed 'Devil's Pool' allows swimmers to safely sit at the edge of the falls during certain seasons
trivia: A lunar rainbow or 'moonbow' can sometimes be seen over Victoria Falls at night during a full moon
The falls are part of two national parks: Mosi-oa-Tunya National Park in Zambia and Victoria Falls National Park in Zimbabwe
There are over 75 species of fish below the falls
David Livingstone, who 'discovered' the falls for Europeans, wrote that they were scenes 'so lovely must have been gazed upon by angels in their flight'
